The image of a function \( f: A 	o B \) is the set of all elements in \( B \) that have at least one corresponding element in \( A \) via the function \( f \).
A group $G$ is called cyclic if it is generated by a single element. This is equivalent to the existence of a surjective group homomorphism $\mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow G$.
Does the concept of a/an Image of Map need to be defined for a definition of a/an Cyclic group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To determine if the concept of the Image of a Map is necessary for the definition of a Cyclic group, we need to analyze the components of the definition of a Cyclic group. The definition states that a group $G$ is cyclic if there exists a surjective group homomorphism from $\\(\mathbb{Z}\\) to $G$. A surjective homomorphism is a type of function where every element of the target set (in this case, $G$) is mapped from at least one element of the domain set (in this case, $\\(\mathbb{Z}\\)$). The concept of surjectivity inherently involves the image of the function, as it requires that the image of the function equals the entire target set. Therefore, understanding the image of a map is crucial to understanding what it means for a homomorphism to be surjective. Without the concept of the image of a map, the notion of surjectivity, and thus the definition of a cyclic group as given, would not be fully understandable.
